terms.definition: A data statement in the form of subject-predicate-object.
The entity or thing being described in a triple.
The property or relationship that links the subject to the object.
The value or entity linked to the subject by the predicate.
A real-world object or concept represented in the graph.
A connection or relationship between two nodes.
A point in the graph representing an entity or a literal.
A structure made of nodes (entities) and edges (relationships).
A graph enriched with meaning, typically using ontologies.
A formal representation of knowledge as a set of concepts and relationships.
The Semantic Web is an extension of the World Wide Web that aims to make Internet data machine-readable.
A standard model for data interchange on the web.
A language for defining and instantiating ontologies.
A query language for RDF data.
A constant value like a string, number, or date in RDF.
A unique identifier for a resource.
A base URI used to group and identify related resources.
A shortcut label for a namespace
A node in RDF without a URI.
The process of deriving new facts from existing ones.
A tool or algorithm that performs inference on a knowledge graph.
A semantic extension of RDF to describe vocabularies.
A category or type of entity.
A specific example of a class.
A property that links an entity to a literal.
A property that links two entities.
A class that inherits properties from another class.
A parent class in an ontology.
The class that a property applies to.
The type of value a property can have.
A collection of terms used in a knowledge graph.
The structure or design of a graph’s data.
A method for connecting data across the web using URIs.
A string used to identify a resource.
A CURIE (Compact URI Expression) is a shortened form of a full URI.
The process of retrieving data about a URI.
Publicly accessible interlinked datasets.
A compact RDF serialization format.
JSON for Linked Data; a lightweight RDF format.
A plain-text RDF serialization format.
A triple with context (graph name) for provenance.
A way to describe RDF datasets.
A model for sharing thesauri and taxonomies.
A tool for building and visualizing ontologies.
A popular RDF database.
A high-performance graph database.
A multi-model database used for RDF and linked data.
A property graph database (not RDF-native).
Company and tools supporting semantic technology.
A Java framework for building semantic web apps.
A commercial knowledge graph platform.
A Java framework for working with RDF data.
A way to validate RDF data shapes.
Combining data from multiple sources via common concepts.
Adding semantic meaning to existing data.
Identifying and merging duplicates of the same entity.
Uncovering new insights from connected data.
Using knowledge graphs to answer natural language queries.
Search enhanced by understanding meaning and relationships.
Providing relevant background information using connections.
Suggesting related items using graph traversal.
Using structured knowledge to support machine intelligence.
A virtual representation of real-world entities powered by KGs.
A graph where edges have a direction (like RDF).
A graph where edges are bidirectional.
A sequence of nodes connected by edges.
A path that starts and ends at the same node.
A subset of the graph where each node is reachable.
The process of visiting nodes in a graph.
A measure of importance of a node in a graph.
The number of connections a node has.
A portion of a larger graph.
When two graphs have the same structure.
Metadata describing the origin of data.
A way to group triples with a name (context).
Assessing the reliability of data in a KG.
Linking data to its source or author.
Keeping track of changes in the graph over time.
A record of changes and access in a graph.
Guidelines for data to be Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable.
Data that describes other data.
A hierarchical classification of concepts.
A set of related terms and synonyms.
A predefined set of allowed terms.
A property used for filtering or categorization.
A human-readable name for a resource.
A human-readable description of a resource.
A keyword or term attached to data for indexing.
A global data space using Linked Data principles.
A server that accepts SPARQL queries.
A collection of metadata about datasets.
Ability of different systems to exchange meaningfully.
Freely available data for anyone to use.
Merging data from multiple sources into a coherent graph.
Representing nodes as vectors for ML tasks.
Neural networks designed for graph-structured data.
Filling in missing relationships in a KG.
Representing concepts based on surrounding relationships.
Connecting text mentions to knowledge graph entities.
Mapping concepts between different ontologies.
Connecting data from different domains semantically.
Tagging data with meaningful semantic concepts.
The process of extracting and integrating data into a KG.
Placeholder
A state in where you can edit your graph.
